As a therapist-know your ethical guidelines and codes. You will be told to do things that are unethical and illegal. At the end of the day, protect yourself and your license because YCS sure does not care about you.

pros: The new leadership listens and invests in staff professionally and personally. YCS leadership has an open door policy and you can reach out to any level of leadership and get a response. There have been advancements in technology that make documentation easier and readily accessible. The client's are happier and get to interact with all staff including the CEO who visits programs and attends individual staff meetings upon request. I'm very hopeful for the agency's future because of the caring leadership and the dedicated staff I work with.
cons: Like everywhere, it's hard to hire people which is not a direct reflection of the agency. If you genuinely care about people and want to make a difference in someone's life YCS is a great place to work.

review_title: You get what you put in
pros: YCS is a huge company with plenty of opportunities for lateral moves as well ss growth. Management on all levels will listen if you seek them out. Clinically there is licensure supervision. Most programs I've seen at the company are like their own family. Your colleagues support you. Recent salary changes have defintley made it more competitive for non profit sector.
cons: As amazing as the clients are, they are also challenging. Anyone working in child welfare needs to be prepared and be conscious of their own history of trauma. But the agency offers extensive training to work with the clients and support for the staff!

review_title: Do not work for this company!
pros: (Sawtelle Learning Center) I learned a lot about working with students with Autism. I met a few great people along the way. Some of the staff are so dedicated. Most of the students and families are also a pro.
cons:
Read the other reviews.!! When I did my research to come here I saw some negative reviews and thought “they must be bitter” or “they’re just negative people.” “No place can remain open and be that bad, right?”

Unfortunately it’s all true. Poor pay, poor management, and it’s not safe to work in schools or residential homes. All staff is disposable and top administration is incredibly unprofessional. There is no respect for what teachers, service providers or staff do in the school. We are merely puzzle pieces moved around to put bodies in rooms to maintain legal compliance. It feels like very little thought is actually put into what is best for students. Furthermore, the curriculum and functionality of academic program is so antiquated that it is ineffective. 
Save yourself and find a more functional positive work place!

review_title: Good Job for psych undergrads, leave once you get the experience
job_title: Residential Counselor in East Orange, NJ
pros:
I worked as a direct care staff, and while working in the group homes, you will definitely get hands on experience dealing with the psychiatric population and how to handle them.  Sometimes you get to go out on great activities depending on the program you are at (concerts, amusement parks, sports games etc.)

If you plan on staying in the Psych field, this job is perfect entry-level work.
cons:
As it is direct care, REALIZE you can be put in danger when working with this population!  Biting, attacking, stealing, fighting, spitting.  Clients can be aggressive, use you as a emotional/punching bag.  You will experience disturbing situations, suicide attempts, cutting.  Be prepared.

Management isn't as great as it should be.  Micromanaging seems to be a favorite of everyone that is in an administrative position.  

Don't expect much potential in promotions.  Management prefers to keep you down and make sure you stay down.  I applied for a transfer to another program to be denied.  I applied for a higher postion (SRT) to be sabotaged.  They rather hire outside the company.

Prepare to work extra shifts as coverage can be limited and call-outs can be frequent.

pros: PTO is generous for employees but you rarely can take it bc of constant short staffing.   There is some good staff, but its extremely rare.
cons: The company goal is to use employees for as much as they can without paying them what they deserve.  Most staff is way under-qualified and not professional at all.  You are constantly worried about the state investigating you because of what other people do on your shift.  Prepare for people that you work with to be grossly undertrained and to not care at all about the job.  Have a lawyer on speed dial at all times.

review_title: Title means nothing expect for the  people at the top  ! they use it to  do as they please
pros: HELPING PEOPLE LEARNING  NEW THINGS Austice ND GIVING     BACK. Every day s a new day to teach and learn new things. Nothing  like  a smile  om a person face .
cons: There can be many  however  giving all you have and not reaching  a person or a child can be the hardest. Even  getting a person to trust  you can be hard and dealing  with parents as well . No matter  what  we are on any job to make things  better the best way we ca, ycs get  rid of the good  people  !!!

review_title: very satisfying, personally and professionally for the first few years.
pros: flexible hours; great co-workers (RA's)
cons: no loyalty for long-term employees -being terminated - if medical leave extended (by couple of wks) as required by MD (note provided); lying, backstabbing " higher-up's"; no job security; made to perform job duties (documentation, client load, etc) not qualified to do at the time for no monetary compensation or recognition then being reprimanded for doing what was supposedly "required" (illegal).

job_title: SRT/Behavioral Assistant in East Orange, NJ
pros: The Pay is good. There is a lot of flexibility. Constantly helping others. There is always shifts to be covered (always hours).  No uniform, dress comfortable.
cons:
The downsides of working at YCS was the management. "Management is very do what I ask or else. I just didn't feel like a valued employer. Here are me reasons; when I was hired I wasn't told that I would be using my car to transporting mentally disabled children. My position was pat-time and expected me to treat the position as a full-time position. You can't expect people to be ambitious and eager to excel in a company when there is no incentive. This is a non-profit organization so I understand resources are limited. Although, the resources are limited you can still show you appreciate your employers. Many employers complained about their paychecks be shortened. There are far to many cons…
-not a valued employer
-shorten your paycheck
-no PTO unless full-time (whenever that happens)
-must volunteer your care to transport clients of all disabilities (very dangerous)
-must volunteer your personal phone SRT are on call 24/7 so they call you whenever they want. they feel they have that right. Why not just give out company cell phones.

job_title: Residential Counselor in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Providing care for behavioral children, working with a good team of clinicians, nurses and case managers. Loved going on different outings and events with the children.
cons: Lack of a true vision for this company. Management very disjointed depending on the region you work in. Lack of volunteered overtime but you make you stay if there is a call out with no warning. Lack of resources and additional help for the children. No raises or recognition for employees. HR very unprofessional towards employees. Company always crying broke but rush to open new houses with under trained staff. Will wait for a crisis in order to fix a problem.

pros: There are some great people who work here who will try their best to support you.  The new CEO will turn this company around, just might take awhile..
cons: Low pay, poor administrative management, no autonomy

job_title: Family Preservation Counselor in Union City, NJ
pros: One of the biggest pros is the fact that it is a pretty relaxed environment to work in. My supervisor is pretty relaxed and does not bother any of the employees as long as all your paperwork is done you should be fine.
cons: The only negative to this company is the salary. Since it is a non-profit company, do not expect to make a lot of money in this company. This could be a could be a good company to gain some office experience. Another negative to this position in particular is that it does require a lot of driving to see the families. It can get pretty expensive with gas.

pros: Working with the Clients, making a difference. Depending on your very flexible with your schedule. My on site management was pretty good.
cons: YCS is very top heavy. OT is not given, HR is very disorganized and not friendly. Pay scale is not generally fare. High cost of benefits. Management's philosophy is everyone is replaceable. Poor employee moral

pros: Everyone working there is very professional and really helpful especially when you are new. The training is the best part about it, free breakfast! When you actually arrive to you school, it is very different than what you trained for. If you care about students with needs and disabilities then you will probably enjoy this job until you meet your administration.
cons:
Principals/Directors do not have a common view on anything. One person might tell you to do it one way, but the other person kind of belittles you because that's not the way it should have been done. You really don't know who to believe because of the different views of how things should be done. I really do feel bad for the children because it is like a jail in this facility. I know they belong somewhere that can handle their behaviors, but the staffing is always an issue. People get moved and rotated and the children have trouble with change as it is, I don't know why they do this. The staff at the "headquarters" is very rude and abrupt especially when you have questions about your payment or any questions at all. It is not a pleasurable place to work for/at and most people stay less than a year. 

 Administration at the YCS Sawtelle facility believes they are correct in everything they say, but again everyone has a different "correct" view. This creates employees getting spoken to and telling them not to do it again. They should be on the same page. 

Also, as a teacher I think we know our students better than anyone else. Before the year starts we have to get our classrooms "approved" on seating arrangements and everything. If we know the students, I do not see the problem. Sometimes students just want to be included and it's all trial and error. They almost do not trust you even as a teacher level and want to do everything themselves, but you do all the hard work.

If you are in need of help such as in a headlock don't assume anyone of higher authority walking by will help. One of my head assistants happen to be passing by in the hallway and knew I needed help and if it weren't for her I probably would still be there in a headlock right now. I understand they they do not help you unless you ask, but it is kind of hard not to help someone in a headlock and just look and walk away very quickly.

pros: Very rewarding working with the youth and helping them turn their lives around for the better. Some of the families are a pleasure to work with.
cons: Some of the families are a nightmare to work with. Also the pay is low especially for those who are starting out and may or may not still be in school. They say they reimburse for mileage and tolls but are VERY slow in doing so... plan to go at least 6 months without being reimbursed.

pros: Great staffs , great enviroment.
cons: NO rooms for growth, people with degree get same pay as those without degree which is not fair.

pros:
Colleagues

It'll prep you if you want to become a correctional officer 
The staff is like family
cons:
Low pay 
No raises
No bonuses

It's Russian roulette if you're alone with any client ....never be alone with a client or clients
IA you're guilty until proven innocent

review_title: Would never recommend this place, not even to my worst enemy.
pros: I have worked here about 10 years, if you are in a school setting, I used my days off to recuperate. If you are in the residential assistance setting, forget about recuperating altogether and there are no real days off for you. Benefits used to be good 10 years ago, unfortunately, now it's time to consider obamacare. Only one Pro i can think of is I met a few great men and women who truly put their blood, sweat, and tears to get the job done, spent money out of their own pocket, went above and beyond their duties to help those kids, only to receive brush off, the backstab, the wrongful and unfounded suspension or terminations, the "being thrown under the bus" by upper management and higher ups so they can wash their hands, pose for their website, magazine, bend over for money from their sponsors at their yearly get togethers without recognizing their staff not even once in my 10 years with a raise.
cons: The majority of the population we worked with were not special needs childre, they were just very misbehaved, aggressive thugs and we were just their stepping stone prior to their extended stay at some juvenile detention center. Let's not kid ourselves. Prepare for them to bite you, fight you, choke you, try to kill you, or just make an allegation against your character for the simple fact that they just might not like you and get away with it without a single consequence from any authority once being cleared. My recommendation to you is if you do get assaulted, do not hesitate to press charges, i cannot emphasize that any clearer. When these little thugs tell you they're going to kill you and your unborn child by punching or kicking your stomach, they are no longer  a child in your eyes, be prepared to take serious action, you have been warned. We did however get maybe less than a handful of kids that really and truly needed our help. It was rewarding to see those seldom few move back to society completely changed. Misogyny is apparently a main requirement to be in a "higher up" position and if you can top that with some addiction to a poison of your choice, be sure you have secured yourself a long term seat in the top dog circle, if you get what I'm trying to say. Don't expect a raise, don't expect anything, don't expect structure, don't expect support from your supervisor or human resource, don't expect anything period, get out while you can.

pros: Working collaboratively as part of an interdisciplinary team with an exchange of ideas to look at cases in a multifaceted way, improving outcomes.
cons: Technology is lagging, pay is lower than comparable jobs. Clinical team can be spread too thin, leading to feeling overworked.
